posts.name: Declan Dunn
posts.cooked:
Hey there! So we’re trying to add some vision to our bot with PhotonVision, using a Raspberry Pi 4 with two AprilTag cameras, both on the same side but offset from each other left and right of the bot so that we can line the bot up to either side of the tag on the Reef. The issue is that we have absolutely no idea where to start, all documentation/example code that I’ve found online seems way to complicated. I know it shouldn’t be straightforward, but is there anyone who can help point us in the right direction or get us started? Thanks!

Alongside this, any suggestions for a more streamlined codebase/any features we should add to our bot software-wise?

Github Repo

posts.name: Krish
posts.cooked:
We’re working on this ourselves and have landed on using a pid to go to absolute position on the field after using the April tags to reset our odometry

A simpler solution we used earlier, use the Y value we got from photon vision, make a pid with a setpoint of zero and feed that value into our drive function then for bumper X alignment calculate the distance from the tag using trig and do the same pid thing

Still kind of new to all this vision stuff myself but thats what I’ve seen work so far

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Your second solution is more or less what our team is doing for alignment.  We’ve calibrated our cameras and are using 3d mode, and then taking the transform and running our PID using that.

posts.name: Declan Dunn
posts.cooked:
Is either of you willing to share what you have so far? I just need to get a good reference lol

Also, I’ve been making some changes based on the Photon docs. If either of you could take a look, I would appreciate it. Sorry for all the questions; I’m the only programmer on our team.

posts.name: Krish
posts.cooked:
nah I get it we only got two robot programmers too. we moved away from that code unfortunately and we’re a cpp team but the general idea is that you want to use the wpilib piscontroller instead of whatever photons example is doing.

here’s some weird pseudocode:

So your making a pid controller that will return the speed you need in order to make the y value that photon vision returns to zero you feed that into your drive similar idea for the x

I hope that helps for now (I’m trying to program on my phone)

some docs to look at:

WPILib supports PID control of mechanisms through the PIDController class ( Java, C++, Python). This class handles the feedback loop calculation for the user, as well as offering methods for return...

The following example is from the PhotonLib example repository ( Java/ C++). Knowledge and Equipment Needed: Everything required in Aiming at a Target.. Code: Now that you know how to aim toward th...

if it helps you here is our repo its all public:

GitHub - FRC1229/Reefscape Contribute to FRC1229/Reefscape development by creating an account on GitHub.

posts.name: Declan Dunn
posts.cooked: So I’ve been working on this nearly all day and I feel like I’m no closer than I was earlier lol I try and set up everything exactly according to the documentation and their example code, but I can’t even get that to work, it scans the tag but doesn’t send any driving code. So I then try and switch out their driving code with the PIDControllers, still giving issues, it doesn’t want to drive or recognize that there is a tag in view. I am worried that how our code is written is too disorganized and verbose (and the fact that we’re using MAXSwerve) to really be able to implement this, because even after getting an autoalign system set up, we still have to figure out path planning and setting it up so it aligns itself to the closest tag, since we’re primarily just using this for coral alignment. I’ll keep looking over your guys’ code, I appreciate you sending it over, I just wish Copilot’s database was up to date so it would know how to properly use the libraries lol.

posts.name: Krish
posts.cooked:
Okay so I was looking through your code I think for the Y you just have to use  if you have calibratied your camera for 3d mode

This code here I think should look more like this

Because your going to get the Y offset the camera to target is to zero

I’m not very familiar with the MAXswerve library so I can’t help with the drive

To calibrate a camera, images of a Charuco board (or chessboard) are taken. By comparing where the grid corners should be in object space (for example, a corner once every inch in an 8x6 grid) with...

posts.name: Declan Dunn
posts.cooked: Ok so I just got rotation to work with the PID controller, so that’s great, but now its just issue after issue trying to set up ranging and such so it can move closer to the target, I think there’s a problem when it is trying to read the current pose as a reference, but it just doesn’t transfer over well, so to actually get it to move closer I have to reset the odometry, which obviously isn’t a good idea. Ill try what you just said and keep you all updated!

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked: What we did was get tag poses from photonvision, then run a PathPlanner trajectory to it.

posts.name: Declan Dunn
posts.cooked: Is there any way I can see your guys’ implementation of this?

posts.name: Krish
posts.cooked: How did you tune pathplanners pids?

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked: We didn’t get any time to test it in the real world. Pretty much relied on the Advantage kit / Advantage Scope / maplesim testing.
